results.content: Essentially you watch the instructor code. There is quite a bit of copy and paste and not much explanation as to what is going on behind the scenes. So, it assumes you know what he's doing. Several sections of the code do not work on a mac and are outdated even on a PC. If you understand all of the technologies already then this course would be fine but then why take the course. I find I am gaining no understanding from the course material. However, it introduces several really cool resources and gives a basic overview of what they are capable of. With some code tweaks you can get them to work on a mac or PC but you have to understand node, javascript, and the technologies being implemented to do so. It's provides some practice in using stack overflow and troubleshooting. What makes it difficult is at times I'm not sure if it's the instructor's code that is causing the bug or my own coding error. They are updating the course apparently and when they do that I'll check it out again and maybe increase this rating.

results.content:
There is a good content in this course, but it is covered quickly without without any detailed explanations on the how or the why of specific topic. The scope of topics that the course tries to cover is also very wide and the use of different technologies  for similar purposes in each unit has left me somewhat frustrated as I feel that I haven't grasped the first technology before moving onto another. This is likely due to the fact that most technologies are taught using a 'copy and paste' method.

Overall, I would so far recommend this course to people who wish to gain a brief insight into specific technologies and packages before delving into the topics in further detail in their own time. If you wish to gain mastery of the technologies covered in this course, expect to spend a lot of time undertaking self-study through documentation or YouTube videos in addition to completing the course.

Be aware that some versions of the packages and databases used in this course have changed a fair amount since this course was created and so Google is your friend.

results.content: Brad is a good (but not a great) teacher. However, there is great value in the course he's produced here. To be able to walk through the guts of 12 distinct and varied Node projects is really valuable. So many Node tutorials cover just a basic hello world web server or they focus on just one application (e.g. a to-do list) in great detail. Brad's course gives the student a rapid and up-close look into a great variety of Node projects, which I really appreciate.
results.content_html: Brad is a good (but not a great) teacher. However, there is great value in the course he's produced here. To be able to walk through the guts of 12 distinct and varied Node projects is really valuable. So many Node tutorials cover just a basic hello world web server or they focus on just one application (e.g. a to-do list) in great detail. Brad's course gives the student a rapid and up-close look into a great variety of Node projects, which I really appreciate.

results.content:
This course is a great way to learn Nodejs plus a lot of technologies.

The issue with the course is that some projects are outdated, so when you try to complete them it gets really hard since you have to do some research to fix the errors from the packages' updates, the instructor response time is OK.

Also, this is a course where you learn by yourself, the projects are explained at a low level so you need to know the programming and web development basics.

Since I had that level, I could learn a lot from this course, it really helped me to understand how exactly NodeJS works, in a really fun and entertaining way.

If you want to learn programming, this is not a course for you, but if you already know a bit of programming and want to learn NodeJS and a lot of technologies, then this course IS for you :)

results.content:
I am a new (entirely neophyte ) to this technology. I believe that this video gave me some new topic related insights to build upon without overwhelming me all at once.

I ran into an issue with the Chat application where the browser pukes on the node keyword 'require'.  Very frustrating and many hours of online researching to find a solution (Browserfy and Webpack suggested). I was under the impression that the beauty of Node.js was that Javascript could be used throughout the development stack. Sure if you keep trying out hundreds of other Javascript frameworks in effort to find compatibility with Node.js.  All of these tools are 'pieced together' in complex puzzle fashion. Hard to see how  any company would invest large sums of money where the code base is mainly Javascript. As a neophyte it is frustrating when you closely follow the instruction video where the instructor's code is working and mine is not.  Particularly when there is no mention of the fact that browsers cannot process Node's  'require' and no recommended fixes  offered during the course.

results.content:
Most of the content is useful if somewhat outdated.  Some of these technologies are older and sometimes unsupported.  No new content has been posted by the author.  
There is a lot of copy and paste especially in the later lectures. But that's understandable once you have sufficiently grasped the concept of what you are copying.
My biggest issue is that the author/instructor has not updated any content nor will he answer any questions beyond a terse "We'll look into that".  This content was generated, put online and abandoned by the author.
The Firebase project specifically (the last and largest project) took many times longer to figure out since each step had to be translated to the most recent version of Firebase.  I've added my notes to the [barely useful] Udemy Questions and Answers forum for future students.
The whole course took me three months to complete working on it (mostly) 5 days a week for 1 or two hours a day.  
A very large amount to different technologies was used throughout.  My goal was to get a basic knowledge of how node works and get myself ready to build a production application.  I feel like I have the basic tools I'll need to attempt to do this.  The hunting for solutions did teach me just as much, or more, than the video lectures did.  But the lectures did provide a template to use and some code explanation of what we are trying to build.  
I can't help but wonder if there is a newer Node class available by a different author.  One that is up to date and currently supported.

results.content:
My original review was much more negative, but in truth there is much good content in the course, and I am learning a lot about JavaScript so the source is meeting my goals. The course has improved in the later lectures, and I am glad that the instructor has redid the lessons to bring them up to date.

My main criticism of the course has to do with the instructor's way of presenting the info, and that criticism still holds for me. He makes too many errors because he seems to be building the project as he goes. It would be much better if he had built it beforehand and worked from a script during the filmed presentation. I understand that in real-life, there are many typos, corrections, etc., but those should not be part of a commercial product which is being sold.

One additional nitpick with the presentation. The instructor uses vague terms like "I will copy this..." and "I will paste it here". I was trying to build the projects being taught in the course, and often I would be looking at my own development environment, and I would have to stop the video to see what "this" and "here" meant. I think it would be better if the descriptions were more specific. For example, "I am copying the eight lines of the index route method, and then pasting them just before the end of the edit route method". More verbose, but it might be easier to follow along for a student whose attention is divided between the presentation and his/her own project.

results.content: I had high hopes for this course.  The style of teaching seemed great and I was excited to follow along with projects to learn as I feel like this is the best way to really dive into a new platform.  The lectures themselves were great and I really do like the teaching style.  However, the content is so dated as to be totally unusable.  Other students have posted comments on the lessons that make some of the lessons possible to get through but after being stuck for a month on a previous lesson (mostly my fault for being out of town and being busy) I finally was able to move on to the next lesson... only to find myself stuck again because the code base is deprecated.  I don't think the original instructor is still involved with the course, it seems to have been sold to a larger organization.  The current instructor organization is quick to answer questions, but not to give very useful feedback.  The most useful feedback comes from other students who have found ways to troubleshoot the course, but even their answers fall short at times and then we're all stuck.  This course is in desperate need of an update.  I understand that re-recording the lectures would take awhile, but even to just have someone go through the course and try to do it with current technology and post updated files and notes on the changes in each lecture would be invaluable.   As it is I'm almost 1/5th of the way through the course and I'm trying to decide if it's worth my time to finish or if I'm better off finding a different course through another provider.

results.content: Very informative in-depth course covering NodeJS web development.  The examples are not trivial and does require user participation in developing and testing the code and these are actual, useful code.  Great exposure to a good number of NodeJS frameworks (express, drywall, kraken, passport, etc.) and other supporting libraries are featured and implemented in the examples.  I'm only half way through and, wow, already learned a tremendous amount - breath and scope of NodeJS development.  Users having some existing knowledge of  HTML / CSS / JavaScript / JQuery  and NodeJS will help make this course easier to follow.  And for me, I'm sorely missing closed captioning (cc).  Even without CC, I'm successfully able to follow both the video and develop/test the actual code examples without the audio.

results.content:
1) Little-to-no explanation when introducing new frameworks, modules or programs such as express, jade or nodemailer. When he does offer an explanation of why he's typing something, it is usually quite general, giving the impression that he himself does not possess an in-depth understanding of the material he is teaching.

2) Presenter seems unprepared, frequently having to troubleshoot or find his own files. 

3) Presenter is vague and unspecific in his directions, telling you to type "this" or move something "here", rather than offering verbose, specific instruction.

4) Presenter did not emulate best practices on several occasions. Examples: using browser's "View Page Source" to copy and paste code, directing everyone to download bootstrap into their project without even mentioning the time and memory-saving CDN bootstrap link reference, duplicating large amounts of code (should not be done even when illustrating another point), no use of browser dev tools when troubleshooting, and the list goes on.

Unfortunately, I can't recommend this for beginning developers. You may code along as he types, but due to the very little actual teaching that takes place in this course, you might as well just copy and paste his project files and save yourself some time.

I can only recommend this to junior level developers who are looking for a nice library of node projects to practice with on their own.

results.content:
EDIT as per request from course team:
There are only 10 projects, not the 12 as advertised - fairly clear.
I am a little surprised, you need more information, as there are many comments, left by me and other students, over several months, in the course Q and A's. As said, I have not completed, currently I need a more productive course, but out of the 10 projects I have tried 6 and of those 3 have the following specific issues:
Section 4 - User Logon System - Validation method uses deprecated and now removed API. API has been deprecated for 3 major versions.
Section 6 - Bookstore - Whole technology stack is dead (> 2 years), is not recommended for new projects - see above warnings and in any case I could not get to build.
Section 8 - Findadoc - Cassandra installation information is outdated and even Q & A's do not include help for installation on a MAC. Even searching I was still struggling even installing and configuring.
This of course is in addition to the early web server issues - section 3, which I had forgotten that I had partially working and was going to return to. Thats actually 4 projects out of six. Thanks to John for reminding me about that one.

Original review:
This course has real potential to be excellent, if you want a 100ft   view of many node technologies, as I did. However as of late 2019 there are only 10 projects, not the 12 advertised, and a number of required technologies / packages used are deprecated. This means packages are incompatible, have numerous vulnerabilities (consider carefully for use in live deployment) and/or the whole package is not recommended for new projects. Hence you will not learn the newest techniques and the provided information / code is starting to break badly i.e. pug is the new jade. Unfortunately Brad is not keeping up with these changes, despite some being prior to the last course update, and out of the first 5 projects 2 need a lot of work to complete.

This course requires old versions of node, express-validation and (possibly npm - yuks) to name the few I have found, so you will have to be willing to install those. However in project 4 Gulp and others are very likely suspects too. You will need to carefully go through all the QAs to find hints of what to do when things fail, even when using the downloaded source code. Unfortunately the answer often just leads to 'I installed an older version of X' so you will have to be prepared to work that out yourself by trying, reading and debugging. In full credit questions where still being answered, but not ones on what depreciated package code, does.

After spending hours on the 2nd project I have finally almost successfully incorporated the new express-validate, which I undertook as a learning exercise, but are not included in the course.

However on the 4th project there are  7 warnings on the 1st install command. The first is about one of the packages we are installing:
'deprecated bower@1.8.8: We don't recommend using Bower for new projects. Please consider Yarn and Webpack or Parcel.', 
the second is about a dependency of one of those installed packages:
"deprecated natives@1.1.6: This module relies on Node.js's internals and will break at some point." 
Hopefully you get the idea, so if you have legacy projects to support this may be a good course for you to learn why you should stay current.

In case you think 'ah warnings ignore them' - the second command 'yo kraken' errors for completely different reasons, whilst just skipping to the end and building the provided project download with 'npm install' fails completely.

As what I am learning is not current node, but how to debug legacy applications, that should now not be written let alone deployed, I am considering the sense of investing time in the rest of this course.
